Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		Sean was constantly worried about being found out.<n><n>### Input<n>I have two cats that have opposite personalities. One of the cats never gives the other cats anything. The other one loves to share her food, toys and beds with the other cats. Which cat is which? <n>I'll give you the answer if you can guess.<n><n>Ask: Is the first cat the kitten?<n><n>### Instreaming<n>- Answer:<n>- Demonstration: Ask the first 4 cats.<n>### Response:<n>- Demontration: Answer yes. <n>-  Answer 3: Is the first cat older than the second?<n>- Demonstrations:Answer: yes.<n>- Response: Demonstration: Answer 2 No <n>- Answer 2. Is the first cat younger than the second?<n><n>### Demostration<n>- Answer:<n>### Response<n><n>### Instructing: How many of the following words are in the list? Choices:  C: 7 D: 11 E: 15 F: 17 G: 29 H: 33 I J: 36 K: 40 L: 50 M: 63 N: 79 O: 83 P: 85 Q: 101 R: 107 S T: 108 U: 117 V: 125 W: 133 X: 139 Y: 146 Z: 157<n><n>### Instrection Answer: F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, T, and Y<n><n>### Comments:<n>### Demo:<n>### Answers:<n>### Comments(Comments):<n>### Demo:The comments and demo are the same.<n>The answers and comments are the same.<n><n>### Demo, Demonsrtion, Comments<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The accountant used a calculator regularly, he kept one at home and one at the what? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n>**D** The answer to this question is the city hall, because a person who has an accountant is in a city.<n><n><input type="button" onclick="submit()" value="Next Qestion" /><n><n>### Demo:<n><n><n>### Instructions: Choose the best answer that completes this sentence.<n><n>How many animals did each family have during the Christmas vacation? <n>* A: Eleven B: Sixteen C: Seven D: Fifteen E: Twelve <n><n>### Demo<n><input type="text" id="answer" name="answer" maxlength="50" autocomplete="off" oninput="this.value.length===this.maxlength && (this.value = this.value.substring(0,this.value.length));" /><n><button type="submit" form="myForm" onclick="this.form.answer.value = document.getElementById('answer').value; this.form.submit();">submit</button><n><n><n><n><n>### Demo and Instruction<n>* What do you think should you put at the end of the sentence?<n>* How do you feel about choosing the best answer?<n><n>### Demo answer:<n><n>![demoimage](../assets/images/demo1.png)<n><n><n>### Next Question<n><input type="submit" value="Next Qestion"/><n><n><n><n><n><n><form name="myForm"><n>  <label for="answer"> Choose the best answer</label><n>  <input type="text" min="0" id="answer" class="form-control" name="answer" onclick="this.blur()"/><n></form><n><n><script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-2.0.0.js"></script><n><script><n>$(function(){<n>  $("button").click(function(){<n>    $('form').on('submit',function(){<n>      var val = $("#answer").val();<n>      var max = $(".form-control").attr("maxlength")<n>      var vlen = val.length;<n>      if(vlen === max && vlen>0){<n>        return false;<n>      }<n>      else if(vlen === 0){<n>        return true;<n>      }<n>    });<n>  });<n>});<n>function submit(){<n>  alert

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? Choices:  A: person B: species C: artichoke D: all mammals E: live animal<n><n>### Response:		A,B,C,D,E<n><n>#### A: person<n><n>- Is a sentient animal<n>- Is conscious<n>- Possesses a nervous system<n>- Is able to remember, learn, adapt and communicate<n><n>#### B: species<n><n>- The totality or aggregate of living organisms of the same general structure, habitat, and sometimes the same class<n><n>#### C: artichoke<n><n>- The flower bud of the vegetable and ornamental plant of the thistle tribe, related to the sunflower and cultivated for the edible choke, an artichoke<n><n>#### D: all mammils<n><n>- The group of vertebrates comprising the Order Monotremata (egg-laying mammals including the duck-billed platypus) and the Order Placentalia<n><n>#### E: live anmals<n><n>- An animal that has life, consciousness, and the capacity to feel and perceive<n><n>------<n><n>### Task: Write a function that takes two strings and two indices as input, then return the length of the common substring between the two strings and the common starting index between the two indices. (This can be done using a separate function or combined as one.)<n><n>- The length of the substring they have in common<n>- The starting index in the first string<n>- The ending index in string 2<n><n>#### Sample outputs<n>Input: "abacb". index: "0,0"<n>Output: "ab", 0<n><n>Input: "abcbc", index: "0,1"<n>Output: "abc", 0<n><n>#### Sample error<n>Input: "bc", index: "3,1"<n>Output error<n><n>Input: "abc", index: "1,1"<n>Output<n><n><n><n><n>#<n><n>### Instructions: Describe the rules for the following game of dice.<n><n>Write the instruction to allow for the following statements. A: a letter after the word in the text B: the character that comes after punctuation C: a letter added to a base word D: a vowel that changes an ending<n><n>#<n>```ruby<n>puts "Your response: #{input}"<n><n>if input==inputs.first<n> puts "Correct"<n>elsif input==inputs[1]<n>  puts "Close"<n>elsif input>=inputs[2] && input<=inputs[3]<n> puts "Correct enough"<n>elsif input=inputs[3] && input=inputs[4]<n>  puts "Correct enough, but not enough detail"<n>else<n>  puts "Sorry, but that is not the correct answer"<n>end<n>```<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Create a recursive function like the one below. A function must be defined on arrays and on objects if no specific types are given. For these tasks, you should use an object that was created earlier. <n><n>### Instuction: Find out how many vowels an array of 500 English letters contain.<n><n>### Function Recursive Solution<n><n>##### Create a new function that would display all vowels (A, E, I, O, U, and Y) of any English alphabet string.<n><n>##### Function Recursive Solution:<n><n><n><n>```<n>function vowelCount ( str ) {<n>  if (str.length === 0){ return 0;}<n>  var string = arrayOfLetters.join('')<n>  return str.match(/[AEIOU]/gi).length || arrayOfLetters.length<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Recursive function on Array<n><n>##### Create an array in which no elements are the same as each other is returned as an object. Return each element as a string and a number. Objects must contain unique arrays.<n><n>##### Array Recursive Solution:<n>```<n>function arrayOfUniqueElements(x) {<n>  if (x === []) return x;<n>  var arr = []<n>  x.forEach((val)=>{<n>    if(!arr.some(v => v === val))<n>    {<n>      arr.push(v);<n>    } <n>  })<n> <n>  return arr;<n>}<n>```<n>## Recursive function for creating an array of the same type as the input.<n>##### Create a recursive function like the code below.<n><n>##### Recursive solution.<n>```<n>function recursiveArrayCreation() {<n>  function innerArrayCreation() { <n>    if (arguments.length === 1) {<n>      return arguments.length;<n>    }<n>    else if (arguments.length > 1) { arguments.forEach(() => innerArrayCreation()); }}<n><n>function recursiveArrayCreator(innerArrayCreator) {<n>  if(typeof innerArrayCreator === 'function'){<n>    if (typeof arguments[1] === 'function') {<n>      args[1](arguments);<n>    }<n>  }}<n><n>var args = arguments;<n>return

Choices:  A: training B: satisfaction C: injury D: beauty E: late<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>import re<n>response = input_in_string()<n>```<n>### Output:A function to take a string return it's lower case letter.<n><n>```python<n>def lower_case( input_word ):<n>    my_string = input_word.lower()<n>```<n><n>```python<n>letter = lower_case(response)<n>print ( letter )<n>```<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>    Demonstration: <n>    Input:You are writing a program to find the total area of a rectangle. <n>    Choices:  1:The height of a rectangle can never be less than the width. <n>              2:The rectangle can be divided into other shapes. <n>              3:The rectangle can be triangular.<n>    <n>    Which is correct???<n>    # Choices:  1, 2,1, 0<n>```<n>### Response: <n><n>```python<n># Input<n>height_width = input()<n># Check if input is 1<n>if height_width == '1':<n>    one = True<n><n># Check if input > 1<n>if height > width:<n>    pass<n><n># Output<n>print('one')<n><n># Or:<n># if (height > width):<n>#     print('two')<n># <n>```<n><n>### Input <n>The teacher has invited the class to a movie tomorrow. (If there is any space between numbers, use it, or add a comma where needed.)<n><n>Assume I received this prompt from my phone, so it is formatted differently.**<n><n>9-2-x-(2-36)<n><n>I am familiar with this operation so I know how to perform it. Since 9-2-9-8 = 61-2-10-3 = 51. The only number that did not cancel out was 9. <n><n>9 can be divided by 2 and x. 9/2=4 and 4x6=24. Subtracting 24 from 36 I get 12. 9-2-4-2=12.<n><n>### Input(Assuming you still reply at the end): I'm only looking for a response that answers the prompt.<n><n>### Output:<n>A response of "9-2-4-(15-26)" is correct.<n><n>## Expected Output: 40<n><n>## Expected Input: 9 cards, Brenda and Mara (brenda has 14 cards less), 9 cars, Janet, 96<n><n>## Expected Response: 134<n><n>### Response Time: <1 seconds<n><n>### Total Time: <1 seconds

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Why:<n><n> -   A is incorrect. Botanic gardens have all kinds of plants, but most contain roses.<n><n> -   B is incorrect. Flowers gardens generally do not sell flowers unless they are to be grown in the home or gifted.<n><n> -   C is incorrect. A backyard is unlikely to contain a diverse variety of roses, unless it is a rose-growing expert.<n><n> -   E is incorrect. Because they are outside, backyards may have roses, but they are not a place to look for unusual kinds of rosa.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A musician is most likely to perform a concerto for clarinet with what type of group? Choices:  A: music store B: orchestra C: jazz band D: rock band E: music studio<n><n>### Response:		Answer "A"<n><n>### Reasoning:A musician is more likely to perform a concert that includes a large number of people. "Jazz" and "rock" are genres that are better represented by smaller ensembles. "Orchestra" is represented by a large ensemble, but also by many different individuals and instruments. "Studio" generally refers to audio engineers.<n><n>### Recommended Reading:<n><n>* [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics&oldid=985064439)<n><n>* [StackExchange Music](https://music.stackexchange.com/questions/35315/how-big-an-orchestra-is-necessary-for-a-concerto-for-clarinet)<n><n>* [Clarinet Concerto by Mozart](https://youtu.be/nkMd0ZKvjTk)

A is the proper answer.<n><n>## Description:In the example below is a simple mathematical statement. Write a response that describes how to solve the problem.<n><n>### Example:I need to know the answer to this question. Will the total cost of shipping my products, inbound freight and taxes, 15% off, equal to 25% of sales?<n><n>### Guidelines:Include the rules, formulas, steps and examples that will help the learner solve the problem. Include any calculations that can be done within the calculator without using the keypad to type in answers.<n><n>### Input  :Sales of the product will be $9,500.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>1. First, we need to look at the key factors involved:<n><n>2. The total cost of shipping = 450<n><n>3. The total cost of inbound freight and 5% taxes = 1420<n><n>4. Total costs = 1870<n><n>5. The total cost of the product = 9500<n><n>6. Cost of sales = $19,900<n><n>7. Cost per product unit  = $160.20<n><n>8. Total cost sales = 950 products<n><n>9. Cost on 950 products = $15,640<n><n>10. Total cost taxes + inbound of cargo or inbound of taxes = $2085.49<n><n>11. Total expense = 1670<n><n>12. Taxes of 15% = $163.45<n><n>13. Freight 15% = 270.59<n><n>***<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input:(25 ‚Äì 8) + 2 =<n><n>### Response:( 41 ) + 8 = 49<n><n>### Input The equation -50 + 7 ‚â• 5 2 √∑ 20 + 6 = -124, what is the value of the fraction -124 / 10?<n><n>### Response : -123 / 10<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demystification:<n>Sunshine is on one side of a window, while shadow is on the other side of the window. In order to figure out if the window is opaque or transparent, one must first see the shadows of the sun and figure out that sunshine is on the same side as the shadow.  After this, one can only tell where the shine is coming from by looking at the outside of the window, and realizing how much light is on the outside.  If the window is transparent, and sunlight is coming from behind the window, then there will be more light on the outside. A cloudy day would look like one side of the window is made out of clouds (or snow), and this would make the window a bit less transparent.  Finally, it can almost never be certain that the window is completely transparent.  A piece of snow (or cloud) could simply partially cover one‚Äôs view, causing light to look like it is from behind the window.  Even if the light from the other side of the room is brighter than what one usually sees, it may not be from behind the window (if there is something covering the entire top half of your eyes at that moment, the other side may look like it is brighter, even if it is not.)<n><n>### Instructor‚Äôs Answer<n>The light will be on the opposite side of the room, since the shadows are outside.  Therefore, the window must be transparent.  In this case the sun must be in front of the room, since there is more light outside. If light was coming from behind, then the amount of light outside would be about the same as it is inside.<n><n>#### Student Response<n>Thank-you for your answer! It would be beneficial if you included a picture. This way we can all see the light being in the front, as you stated. Although

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does reckless driving lead to on a person? Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		Reckless drivers can incur injuries to themselves and to others. In addition, they can cause traffic jams as a result of the accident. Lastly, they may cause tiredness to themselves and the other drivers because of the anxiety of being aware or the accident.<n>### Note: You may be prompted to provide any of the following response formats: short answer, fill in the blank, multiple choice, true/false.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Input:The number that is 200200 more or less than 1669894 is?<n><n>### Response<n><n>You are a student of grade four in elementary school. Your class has 318 students. You and the other students work in five math teaching groups. In each group there are 60 students. The number of students working in each group is 60. <n><n>### Instructions to write the algorithm to the problem of finding the number of groups and students working in them.<n><n>### <n><n>#### Write the description of the problem.  Write the description of the solution to be carried out by the program. Write your programs. Test your programs. <n><n><ol>\item <ol>\item <ol><n><n>```{admonition}<n>Solution <n>:class: info <n>```<n><n>:start:<n><n>```python<n>def group(n, m)<n># This function takes N and M as arguments and returns M groups <n># of size N. The solution is a function, so it should be marked as f <n># function. The arguments of the function should be marked as parameters of the function.<n><n>    groupsize = m # We will work with the value of m by default, if another group size is wanted;<n>    while n<0: # Looping through all possible negative cases<n>        n+=groupsize<n>        <n>    return sorted(list(itertools.combinations(range(n), groupsize)))<n>```<n><n>```python<n>print("The total number of groups:")<n>numGroups = int(input())<n>print("The number of students in each group:")<n>numStudents = int(input()) # Default to 60<n><n>totalGroups = group(n, m=numStudents) # You can set the number of groups, if there are too many<n>```<n><n>```<n>The total number of groups<n>```<n><n>```json<n>The number of students in eahc group<n>```<n><n>```pyo<n>>>> totalGroups = group(n=4, m=30)<n>>>> numGroups = len(totalGroups)<n>>>> numStudents, numStudentsgroups = 180, 6<n><n>>>> len(totalStudents)<n>270<n>

When you multiply a fraction by a whole number, your answer needs to be in that exact same fraction's place. "<n><n>### Response B:<n>"Answers to simple fraction problems need to be in the form of a fraction also."<n><n>### Correct Answer:<n>A is incorrect<n><n>### Instriction:<n>Tarshia has just bought a 1/8 car. The same rule applies to Brenda, she has (B)211-4=207. <n>Let's assume that we (J) have 1 cards. (1+1/2 +3*1/2) = 211/2+207/2+1/2 =206+204+1 = 411-1 =210.<n>Therefore, There are 271 cards are there.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		<n>If I had to do the work:<n><n>- If Brenda has 1 times the number of cards that Janet does it would be equal to 1 + (the number of cards - Janet's)<n>- If I had 40 then the number of cards I have would be equal to 20 + (50 - 15) + 18<n>- So I end up with 211.<n><n>Output:<n>C<n><n>### Answer:<n>If I had done the work correctly:<n>- I asked them to make guesses for the possible numbers of cards they may have left and I was right at getting the whole problem solved.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Write a response that adds the values of the variable b in b and c in c. The results should be recorded in variables a and d with results printed to the console.<n><n>### Partial code:<n>```<n>def square(x):<n>    return x*x<n>'''<n><n><n>a = 1<n>def square(x) :<n>    return x *x<n><n>b = square(2)<n><n><n>#c = square(3)<n>c = b + 5<n><n><n>#print("The value of x is", x)<n>print("The value of a is", a)<n>print("The square of b is", square(b) )<n>print("The square value of c is", square(c) )<n><n>```<n>### Response: Code:<n>```<n>#Python<n>#b = 7<n>a = 1,<n>square(2)<n><n>The value of a is 1<n>The value of b is 7<n>### Python<n>print("The value in b")<n>print("The value is in a")<n>```<n><n>### Expected:<n><n>```<n>The value in b<n>The value is in a<n>#The value of x is 2<n><n>```<n><n>

Choices: A: 1 B: 9 C: 10 D: 1,001<n><n>### Response : Answer Question D<n><n>### Input and demonstration:<n><n>>  Write a function that takes a string and returns the number of repetitions of characters found in the string. <n><n>> Example 1: given "aaa", the function should return 3. <n><n>>   Example 2: given "abcdefdefghij", the function should return the number of repetitions for each character, and the answer will be: <n><n>>   1-a,e 3-c,f<n><n>>   2-b,g,h    <n><n>>   3-d,i,j<n><n>> Solution 3: <n><n>>  Let n be the number of elements in the array, n<= stringLength<=arrayLength in this case. For every a in string, if a is not in array, we record the difference between stringLength and arrayLength, the difference is 1, otherwise find the smallest and biggest stringLength and subtract a-the biggest stringLength, and then sum all the differences, you can get the result directly.<n><n>>   Let's first write all the possible characters in the string into an array,<n><n>>   Array[stringLength]=string.<n><n>>   And then loop over every element in string,<n><n>>     For(i=0;i<stringLength;i++){  <n><n>>        if(!array[i]++){    //if the current character is not in array,   <n><n>>            //then record the biggest diff, let diff=stringLength-the biggest one,   <n><n>>            <n><n>>               diff=stringLength-biggest string;   <n><n>>       <n><n>>            array[stringLength+1]=string.charAt(i) ;  <n><n>>            <n> <n>>         }else if(array[i]>stringLength)  <n><n>>{    //current character in the string is bigger than the max in array,   <n>        <n>>         array[stringLength]=the smallest value in the array (we do this to maintain order);]

At first, it was thought that the different species of flowers or animals were the result of the separation of certain areas through time. <n><n>### Response Choice A(Aristotle)<n>    The Theory of Evolution is a very broad description of how evolution works, it is best summarized by the quote from Charles Darwin. However, it was not until the later generations that this theory was taken seriously, and began to be experimented upon. The Greek philosopher Aristotle wrote the first book ever on biology, Theopreus. Theopreus focused mainly on the biology of humans, but was later turned into a medical text by Galen. Aristotle believed everything had an internal and external quality, he viewed life as an upward progression. Although Aristotle‚Äôs findings are outdated, it was one of the first theories on the idea of evolution.  <n><n>### Instructions Answer these multiple choice question<n><n><n>### Demostration Input: Find how many 3-digit numbers are even. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		The cow would come outside even  after the storm had passed. It wouldn't leave _____ A: meat grinder. B: stable. C: red barn. D: gate E: Green field<n><n>### Input<n>The old lady wanted to use $240 for school supplies, but she didn't have the money for everything, how much money did she have left?<n><n>```python<n>answer = float(input("How much money did she have? "))-(float(input("How much did she want to buy?  "))/ float(input("How many was she buying?  ")) *float(input("How many cents was she getting from each thing?  ")))<n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>### Output<n>There is no answer<n><n>### Explanation<n>You need to use the python input to take the values that were given to you and put them into formulas as follows:<n>How much money did she want to buy x/ x + y = z<n>How much did she want how much she got how many she got<n><n>If the old lady had<n>$420.00 to spend on school supplies, and wanted to spend 60 dollars, how many things would she need to get 240 cents back for her change?<n><n>If the old lardy had $420.0 for her school supplies and wanted 60.00 she needed to know how manny things shw could buy to get back 2.4 from her change that is: How much did she want x How much did she want How manny things did She  buy How many 100ths of a cent was she getting from the 60.0 = x = (420.0 - 60.0) or x= 420.0-60.0= 0.00(0.00 is for the decimal) The next part is asking h ow many things she needed to buy = 0.00/ 10 = 0.03 or 3 she needed to spend 3 times her change to get 24.0 back for the change of 420.<n><n>### Task: <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A person with brown skin may share that skin with whom? Choices:  A: finger B: good health C: own family D: friends E: people<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>    var brownSkin = [ 'good health','family', 'people' ]<n>var answer = "None of these..."<n><n>    var flag = false<n><n>    for (i in brownSkin) {<n>        if (answer.indexOf(brownSkin[i])!= -1) {<n>            flag = true<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>    if (!flag) {<n>        answer = 'none of these'<n>    }<n><n>```<n><n>### Inputs:A person asked for the total of how many? Choices:  (1) two; (2) four; (3) six; (4) eight<n>Answer:<n>```<n>    let totalCount = 0<n><n>    for (let i = 1; i <= 8; i++) {<n>        totalCount += 2<n>    }<n>```

If Mark has 2 fewer books than Aaron, then how many books do they have altogether?  '<n><n>### response<n><n><n><n><n>```<n>Aaron has 7 books more than Mark. If Mark have 2 fewer books than 5 more books than Aaron, so the 2 fewer books Mark have are the 2 less than 5 more books Mark have, so the 2 less than Mark's books are 5 less than Aaron's books.<n>So Mark's books are Aaron's less than 5 and Aaron has 7 more than Mark's books, which means that Aaron's books are Mark's books plus 5, and so Aaron's books plus 2 are Mark's books. so if we add these together we can get there final equation that Mark has 3 more books than Aaron. <n><n>100 - 2 < 3 - 11 < 25;<n>Mark's books are 25 < Aaron's books;<n>Aaron's books are 3 < 5 < 25...(because we added 2 times 5 to it).<n><n>```<n><n><n>#### Input:What two values make the following true? Brenda has 42 less cards than Mara, giving her 35. Janet has 31 more cards than Mara, so she has 53.<n><n>### Response 1: <n><n>## Explanations:<n>The response should state that the two choices are incorrect. Answer choice D should be E; plugging in at a building is a strange thing to do, just as plugging in at a school would be. Answer choice A should be B; basements and schools are buildings, so plugging in at a basement or school is a strange thing to.<n><n>### Expected Explanation:<n><n>### Your task is to determine the correct word to use based on a description of the card deck. D. 3<n><n>### Response :<n>D<n><n>> Example:<n>```python<n>a = 0<n>b = 0<n>c = 1<n>d = 0<n><n>a += 1<n>b += 1<n><n>print(a)<n>print(b)<n>print(c)<n>print(d)<n>```<n><n>```<n>4<n>1<n>2<n>0<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? Choices:  A: georgia B: the south pole C: kitchen cupboard D: italian restaurant E: boil eggs<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think that it was C: the kitchen cupboard.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Input:Janet has 9 cards, brenda has 9 and mara has twice as many as Janet. Therefore brenda has 18 and mara has 26, Janet has 15 left. <n>Mara has 40-15=25 cards. <n> Janet has 18-25=3 more than 18. therefore they have 12 more, but brandy doesn't have any and the total is 28. Janet has 3 cards more than Mara. Therefore Janet has 3 more cards than brenda. Therefore Janet has more than brenda.<n> Janet had 9 cards more than brenda, therefore 9+3=12, Janet has 211 cards.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>There was a sauce pan used only for marinare, where was it kept A: Georgia B: The south pole C: Kitchen cupboard D: Italian restaurant E: Boil eggs <n><n>### Response 2:<n>I think that the saucepan was kept in D: kitchen cupboard.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n><n>### Response:		<n>If someone was scuttling, you would think he was moving fast. However he is crawling slowly and was being hindered.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Output<n><n>`Janet has 9 cards  <n>More than Brenda  <n>Mara has 40 cards  <n>Less than 150`<n><n>### Code:<n><n>```c<n>char question[]="Janet has 9 ";<n>char aAnswer[]="cards   More";<n>char bAnswer[]="than Brenda";<n>char cAnswer[]="40 cards";<n>char dAnswer[]="Less  ";<n>char eAnswer[]="150";<n><n>char tempLetr[20] = {'a','b','c','d','e'};<n><n>int getCard(char *answer){<n>    <n>    return(atoi(answer+5));<n>    <n>}<n><n>int main(){<n>    char userAnswer[20];<n><n>    int aQuestion,aCard,bQuestion,bCard,cQuestion,cCard,dQuestion,dCard,eQuestion,eCard,answer;<n>    answer=0;<n><n>    srand(time(0));<n><n>    for(int i=0;i<9;i=i*2+1){<n>        aQuestion=rand()%9+1;<n>        aCard=rand()%101+1;<n>        bQuestion=rand()%89+1;<n>        <n>        bCard=rand()%99+1;<n>    }<n><n>    printf(" Janet has cards%3d ",aQuestion);<n>    printf(" More than ");<n>    printf("Brenda%3d  ",bQuestion);<n>    printf("%3d  \n",aQuestion);<n>    //a question and an answer<n><n>    cQuestion=rand()%1320+1;<n>}<n>    <n><n>```<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? Choices:  A: persuade B: slept C: take center stage D: challenge E: speak clearly<n><n>### Response:		The lady was telling the story for one and only herself, what a waste of time for an audience. I guess she wasn't the shining stars of the world.<n><n><n>### Instructions: Write a short, creative response to the following scenario. **You may not copy the scenario into your response; you may only use it to generate your response**.<n><n>One day you were sitting with all of your friends during a recess, and you were talking about your favorite teachers. You said that one is mean and makes students do many stupid assignments, while another is boring and you are forced to sleep during her class, the third one is nice and talks to you just like friends do, and the last one treats you as if you were her kids and gives you presents every time you get back from a vacation.<n><n>After talking about this, you decided to make a list of pros and cons comparing your teachers to animals in the jungle. You chose the lion, tiger, crocodile, elephant, wolf, fox, monkey, frog, and rabbit as names for the pros and cons respectively.<n><n>Luckily, you had to go to class after lunch, and you lost the piece of paper where you wrote the names of the animals.<n><n>### Response<n>The teacher was mean and boring. I didn't like her class at all and had to make a list about how she was worst teacher. So after a class I lost the list she made me make and now she has a huge list of animals with their pros and cons. It would be terrible if she found out. The lion she treats best because he is king of the jungle. The tiger is next because he works the hardest and always stuns her classmates with math problems she gives. The crocodile came next because he has a boring face and always sits like he's bored. <n>The elephant is last because she is loud, smelly,and makes everything she touches ruined. <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Sun has the ability to change quickly and move from day to night, also with this the temperature changes very quickly<n># Solution #1:<n>```<n>def num_cards_all(first, second, third, n=9):<n>    second = second-first<n>    third = third - 150 <n>    return second + third + n<n><n>num_cards_all(brenda, janet, mara, 211)<n>```<n><n># Solution #2: <n>```<n>def num (first, second, third): #function to take the number<n>    second -= first<n>    third -= 150<n>    return (second + third + 9)<n><n>num ( brenda, janet)<n>```

If there is one student per square mile and we also know that half of all male students are 8 years old, then the number of 8 year old boys in Denver can be estimated to be 2,923. <n><n>## Solution1:<n><n>**Expected Time Spent:** < 45 minutes. <n><n>#### Solution1-Puzzle<n><n>Input : 11280-739<n><n>Solution:<n><n><n>```py<n>solution = 387<n>```<n><n><n>#### Solution1 - Problem Understanding<n><n>##### Problem Statement<n><n>Input : How many 8 year old in Denver? <n>#### Soltion : 8 year old - 8 / 2 = 4 years x 365 = 1530 days<n><n>How many 8 year boys are in Denver - 11288-1530= 9758<n><n>Input : How Many 11 year'old girls are in Denver? 1/3 of all school age girls. <n><n>10,410 school age girls are in Denver.<n><n>11,110 girls have already taken driver's license.<n><n>211 girls have turned 11 in the previous year.<n><n>So, there are 110,011 children in Denver.<n>#### Soltion : Take 1/3 of total children.<n><n>If boys are 50/50, then 5715 boys.<n><n>If boys and girls are 50/40, then 1663 boys.<n><n>If girls are 50 and boys are 40, then 4624 girls.<n><n>```py<n>denver_boys_per_100000 = 5715<n>denver_

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:How can you get the attention of a person across the room? Choices:  A: board ship B: shout at C: smile at D: cross street E: feel happy<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n><br><n><n>### Instructions:<n>In these problems you are to write and answer the questions. <n>Each problem may have more that one part, which are indicated in the problems.<n>A question can have more than one correct answer. Please provide all answers you find.<n><n>### Problem:<n>How do computers calculate a geometric average? Choice A: divide everything and bring them to a common denominator.<n>Choice B: multiply everything and bring them to the lowest denominator<n>Choice C: add up all the numbers and divide by the total number.<n>Choice D: you must give exact answers. No approximations can be correct.<n>Choice E: All of the above<n><n><n>### Answer:<n>C<n><n><br> <n><n>### Problem <n>What is the formula for computing the sum of the digits of a number?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>(10^n) * (number)<n><n><br> <br> <n><n><n>### Instructons: Answer the following multiple choice question that describes a task.<n><n>### Input<n><n>- Mary has 5 more marbles than John has.<n>- Peter has twice as many marbles as Mary.<n>- If Julie has 3 fewer marbles than John, how many marbles does Julie have?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>I will take the sum of the answer as 259.<n><n>### Responce<n><n>C<n><n><pre><n>  Mary has 5 more than John has. (51 marbles)<n> Peter has 100 marbles more than Mary has.<n> Julie has 5 less than Peter has. <n> (55 marbles)<n>  So, Julie has 3 less than John has and 5 more than John.<n></pre><n>

C and d<n><n>Those both have cell walls: the animal cell, the plant cell, and the amoeba. She found that her collection contained 51 species which are not native to the island. For 7 of those species, only a single specimen was collected. If there were no repetitions of an individual species, how many different species did she collect?<n><n>### Response<n>There were 6 countries, she has to subtract 51 from 6 (6-51=1) and the answer is 4.<n><n><n><n>### Reference<n>https://github.com/nvajac/todo-app<n><n>

Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n><n>### Response:		Obtuse angles could be acute, but not bright.<n><n><n><n><n><n>----------<n><n><n>## Input:In which direction do you add the negative number? <n>Choices: A: subtract B: 2 o'clock C: subtract D: clockwise E: both<n><n>## Response:  B: 2 o/c<n>----------<n><n>## Instructions: A cube with each side measuring 14.32cm has its dimensions reduced to 1/2 their original values in an isometric view. How many cm is its width?<n><n>### Demnortiation: <n><n>A picture of a cube which contains all 3 sides lengthed 14.3cm and the width is 7cm.  The other two sides are not displayed.  To convert to isometric view, we make 1/2 the sides length and make the width be twice as long.<n><n>The length of each side of the cube is 14.3/2 = 7.655cm.  The breadth of the cube is 7.65cm.  The width is 7cm/2= 3.5cm.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The answer to this question is 6.7cm for the length of a side of the cube and 3.5cm for the width of the cube.<n><n>----------<n><n>## Input:Five years ago, what did you do on your birthday?(12/10/2006)<n><n>### Demostration: <n><n>Five years ago or 12/10 is when I turned 8 years old. A picture of a birthday card is displayed followed by a smiley face which is the answer to my birthday on 12/17 this year.<n><n>When five years ago is divided by 12, the answer is 0.41666667. When the quotient is rounded to the nearest thousandth, the answer is 4.166667<n><n>When 12 is divided by 0.41 and the result is rounded to the nearest integer, the answer is 28. This is the answer to my age on my birthday this year. 12/11 is my birthday this year and 12.11 years is the answer

What is a computer program?<n>  * A single part of a program.<n>  * A series of commands performed in logical order to achieve a goal.<n>  * A set of commands performed in an illogical order to achieve a goal<n>  * The process of transforming human-oriented instructions into machine-oriented instructions<n><n>2. Define Programming is ‚Ä¶<n>  * Writing or creating instructions executed by a set of computer instructions.<n>  * A code which is written for the computer to execute, containing some or all the commands used to develop a software program.<n>3. _________________________ means you can do anything with code that an average person can do.<n>  * Aesthetics<n>  * Inhibiting<n>  * Restricting<n>  * Limiting<n><n><n>---<n>2.2 Computer System Fundamentals:<n><n><n>##### 2.2.1 What do we call someone who can speak different programming languages to create programs?<n><n>2.2.1.1 A: The most frequently miscalled word, and one of the most commonly misconcepted words, in programming is ‚Äúvariable‚Äù. A variable is a storage unit that holds a value (i.e., a number, a letter, or another item of data).<n>2.2.2.2 What are the three parts of a computer?<n><n>##### 3.1 Computer system hardware (or just hardware in short) is all the tangible parts that make up a computer.<n><n><n>3.1.1 An _____________is what users see, or "experience." (Or, more commonly, what they actually use.)<n><n>##### 4.2 A computer has only hardware (including the peripherals) and also has software.<n><n>4.2.1 Which among the following are considered peripherals in the computer system?<n>3.3.1 An Application or software package is a computer program that performs a task. It is a set of software components that work together to perform a defined function.<n>3.3.2 An OS

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where do bees congregate with red flowerS? Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		D<n>1. Janet has 128, so that gives us 130 for Brenda. 131- 128=3. 130-3=127. so we have to add 1 more to get 128. <n>2. Janet has 9+ 3 =12. 12+3=15. Multiplying by 2 we get a total of 30 cards for Janet. 30+15=45, 45-40=5, this gives us 5+ 20 which equals 25...<n>3. We only have to subtract this once which gives us 5. Janet will have 29 cards, Brenda will have 128-5=123 and Mara will have 20x2 =40. Total we have is 40+29+123=211. This is the correct answer.<n>4. I have decided that I will write the steps using a tree diagram, which will include Janet as our root, Brenda with 9, Mara with twice as many, Janet- Mara which would be 21 and 40-21=19.  This will get us to Janet. 128 is the end. <n>5. I have also written the steps in order to complete the task. <n>I chose the answer. The only reason this answer D wasn't 41 is because the question is not specific and could have been either 3 or 41, but for the question, D was the closest to the question in number sequence.<n><n>### Extension Question<n><n>What if Brenda gets left with 11 cards and Mara gets left with 38. Is the answer the same as Janet has 11+3 = 14 so that is 40% of the answer which is 14x 2 = 28, so this gives mara 38- 28= 10 and Janet 11-10= 2. So the answer would be 29, which would also be the correct answer because it is 30% of the total amount of cards? Brenda and Janet would have 32 which equals half of the

Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		<n>What's the answer B<n><n>### Challenge(Mentor only) :<n>Challenge the response to the student's response, without revealing the answer. It's possible to challenge the answer, but you should focus on suggesting improvement in what the student has written, not just point out where they are technically wrong.<n><n>### Checking the response:<n>This gives you the opportunity to check in again with the student, make sure you understood their response, as well as their thought process.<n><n><n>### Bonus Challenge(Mentor - if you can, feel free to add if you'd like)<n>Bonus Challenge: This is an optional add-on that is useful for those who get the prompt response right with a high degree of accuracy. This helps to differentiate a very good response from a very great response.<n><n><n>## Additional Instructions(Mentor only):<n>This might help you explain the prompt a little better if you use this:<n>1. Make a prediction about what the student's answer might be:<n>The student may suggest the answer is in letter A<n>2. Provide hints about what could be improved in the answer:<n><n>(If the answer is right, you can suggest they focus a little more on the way they word the answer. You can also suggest they come up with something more original.)<n>This prompt can be modified to be used with just about any subject, I've used it with mathematics often.<n>To make it so it's easier for the students to review, the instructor adds something like:<n>><n>>```<n>> <img src="example.jpg"/><n>> ```<n><n><n>## Add a GIF:<n>(If you do it, keep in mind it's probably best to use GIFs in the past tense)<n><n>## Add a Video:<n><n>### The Code for this lesson<n><n>### Additional code to be added to make it work

Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>*A* - train station<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following numbered questions.<n><n>### -1:How many hours is 2/3 of 1000? -1:How many grams is 6/3 cups?<n><n>### -3:How many pencils are less than 10? -4:How many blocks is less than 100? -5:How many times less than 10 is less?<n><n>```python<n>[1,2,3,4,5,6,7]<n>def mainfunction():<n>    a=int(input())<n>    b=0<n>    def getvalue():<n>        return a<n>    def subtract():<n>        b=a-getvalue()<n>        return b<n>    print(subtract())<n>mainfunction()<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: In what year did the United Nations begin? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The little girl was raised selfish, she didn't even care when she was doing what? Choices:  A: crack B: antipathy C: being mean D: disinterest E: unfeeling<n><n>### Response:		The little girl was being raised selfish.<n><n>Output:Janet has 9 cards<n><n>### Demo answer:Input:(Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda), (Mara has 2 times more cards than Janet), (Mara has a total of 211 cards), (9 + (2 x 9)) = 43.<n>Input:(The little girl was Raised Selfish), (She didn't even care what) = A, (She didn't care about crack), (She didn'th care about antipathy), (She didn' care about being mean), (She didn' t care about disinterest), (She didn'care about unfeeling).<n><n># Write a python program that will implement the operations of the above instruction.<n>```<n>'''Write a python program that will implements the instruction.<n>'''<n><n># Get the user input.<n>n = int(input("Enter the total of the cards?"))<n><n># Find Brenda's cards<n>Brenda_cards = n - 9<n><n># Find mara's cards<n>Mara_cards = 9<n><n># Print brenda's cards<n>print("Brenda's cards: ", Brenda_cards)<n><n># Print Mara's cards<n>print (Mara_cards)<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		<n>- C: Hyperventilation! (hyperventilation is when you breathe faster, which gives you more oxygen and your body releases CO2 that is why you can't do it in the mountains because the altitude of the air is smaller and there is more oxygen, and hyperventilation can give you headache if you do it in the mountains)<n><n>### Input<n>A: When she called I went to the phone. B: She called me and I went to the phone then. C: When she called I came to the phone. D: She called and I came to the phone then. <n><n>### Response<n>Correct <n>It depends of point of view, but both answers would be wrong it wouldn't make a lot of sense, why when she called she would call herself? That is the reason that A is not really a good answer because that is not how English works but B is good it is just grammatically wrong because they are not in the same order.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		<n>To go forth : <n>F <n>To tally back:<n>B<n><n>### Instrction Response:<n>Given this information:<n>B is an anagram of back and back is a synonym of reverse. <n><n>### In the above, what information might have been omitted?<n>Anagram of forth<n><n>### What rule does the programming algorithm follow?<n>Anagram<n>For this problem the algorithm follows an anagram rule to transform the letters of the word "Forth" to solve the problem.<n><n>### What is the outcome when this rule is applied?<n>The outcome when the algorithm is applied would be (f=9 oth w r a t h)<n><n>### How many inputs are present in this algorithm (including the programming function, but not including inputs on a screen or from a keyboard)?<n>1<n>Because an anagram rule is used to find the outcome, one input is required.<n><n>### Which of these variables appear to be constant?<n>i, j, k, n, b<n>The variables i, j, k, and n are all input variables because they change according to the value of b.<n><n>### If there were a variable, say 'g,' that did not change (regardless of b) is this a constant variable or a changing variable?<n>g is changing and variable because its value can be anything at different states. There is no restriction on the function that should be maintained so its value may get altered with time.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to see a lizard in its natural habitat but I do not speak Spanish, where would I go? Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### 1. Write code that creates three new variables that are integers and named number, x, and amount. The variable x will contain a number and the variable amount will contain an expression that is a multiple of x.<n><n>### 2. Write code that checks if a variable x is empty. If x is empty, then print ‚Äúempty‚Äù. If x is not empty, then print ‚Äúnot empty‚Äù.<n><n>### 3. Write code that prints the values of two variables where the value of one is a multiple of the other. If one variable contains no values, then print ‚ÄúNot a multiple‚Äù, otherwise print ‚ÄúA multiple of‚Äù.<n><n>### Code:<n>```<n>import sys<n><n>def main(size=None):<n>  if size == None:<n>    print('you need to pass a size argument')<n>    sys.exit(1)<n><n>  numbers = input().split()<n>  x = [x for x in range(1, size + 1)]<n>  amount = None<n>  addAmount = 1<n>  for number in numbers:<n>    print(addAmount)<n>    addAmount *= 10<n>    if number!= '0':<n>      x.append(int(number))  <n>  for number in x:<n>    if amount == None:<n>      amount = number<n>    else:<n>      if amount % number == 0:<n>        print('a multiple of', amount)<n>    if number > amount:<n>      addAmount *= 2<n>      if number % amount == 0:<n>          print ('in', amount)<n>    else: <n>      print('not a multiple of', number)<n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>  main() <n>```

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is A, because a shadow is usually cast when light shines on an object. A shadow would not normally appear on a bright light because there is no space for a shadow, such as a brightly lighted building or bridge. Shadows tend to appear on a more solid object.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: What is the temperature of water when its density is 0.985 and it weighs 1.00 gL? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		Four other choices are: grocery store.<n><n>### Input (cont)How many feet high is the cellar?<n><n>### Response (cont): 25<n><n>### Input.You are given 4 pounds of sugar (in the form of individual grains). You want to make cookies and need exactly 2 pounds of sugar (as a lump). Do you need 0 or more sugar?<n><n>### Answer(1): 0<n><n>### Answer (2): 1<n><n>### Explanation.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>We created this function, which takes a list of choices, and the user input.<n><n>#### Code:<n><n><n>```py<n>import time<n><n>def multiple_choice_validation_checker(input_choices, response):<n>    try:<n>        for c in input_choices:<n>            if input_choices.index(c) == response:<n>                pass<n>                response_list = response<n>                print("Correct")<n>                time.sleep(4)<n>            else:<n>                print("Sorry, that's not true. Try again. ")<n>                if response!= None:<n>                    response_list = response_list  + ',' + response<n>                else:<n>                    response = ''<n>    except:<n>        print("Sorry that's not correct. Try again. ")

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling.  What might he do to get away from them? Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The best choice is E: make art.<n><n># Task<n>In this task, you will create an object which accepts a set of parameters of the form: { key: value}. You can test this code with the examples above.<n><n>``` javascript<n>function validateDirections(directions) {<n>  return directions.reduce(function(response,currentElement) {<n>   response += currentElement.map(function(element) {<n>    return element.value;<n>   });<n>   return response;<n>  }, '');<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In this response:<n><n>- validateDirections is called in the function: reduce.<n>- This function: validateDirections, accepts a key and a value.<n>- In this case, the value is the direction in the list that we want to change.<n>- The response is the same value in a different order. <n>- We can determine the number of elements we need, by using a map.<n>- Every time we loop in a map, we are calling the value function, which takes two variables and gives a result.<n>- The number of results from the function, is the number we need for our map.<n>- Finally, we need to create a function that concatenates all our outputs.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What do people look for when competing against someone? Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The answer is A.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Edge is a very specific term that refers to an advantage that one competitor, (edge holder), has over another competitor (edge holder).<n><n>Edges provide a strategic advantage with respect to competing.<n><n>### Input<n>How do you determine the most efficient schedule?<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>The answer is C. <n><n>### Exploration:<n><n><n>The answer would be C. "Most Efficient schedule" is the same as "the Least Cost schedule"; where "Efficient" and "least cost" could be interpreted as "most profit"...<n><n><n>The Efficient Schedule  is calculated by<n>(Total Unit cost / Available Production units)<n><n>Total Unit cost is used instead of Price per Unit for this exercise. <n><n>The Efficient schedule is the best schedule for a manufacturer. Using the Efficient schedule will prevent inventory build up and minimize working capital requirements.<n>

Choices:  A: grocery store B: refrigerator C: freezer D: plate E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* C) Freezer<n><n>```python<n>from pprint import pprint<n><n>N = 2<n>arr = [10, 15, 10, 21,22]<n><n>l = [x*N +N-1 for x in arr[:-1]]<n><n>print("l", l )<n><n>r = [x*N for x in arr]<n><n>print("r",r )<n>a=l+r<n> <n>print a<n><n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would humans do when their legs are tired? Choices:  A: sit down B: make mistakes C: have sex D: reproduce E: excrete<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question.<n><n>## Instructions: Write a program that takes the number of legs of two people. And compares their legs to each other.<n><n>### Input Format:<n>Input the number of legs for person A. The program will ask you to type in the number of the person A. It will then give you an example of person A input so you can practice. Then it will ask you to input the number of legs for B, then it will ask you to type the number for B, then again give you an example of the B input. It will keep doing this until you give a different number for each input.<n><n>### Processing:<n>The program will print out the amount of legs person A has. If the number of person A is less than the amount of person B, it will print out the message A: less than B by number of legs. If the number in person A is equal to B, it will print: A: equal to B. It will only print this if the amount of legs for person A equals to the amount of B.<n><n>If the amount of person a is greater than the amount of B. It will print out the message: A: greater than B by the amount of legs. Finally the program will print out the sum, using the amount of legs for A and B.<n>

Pressing O at this point takes you to the end.<n><n>If you choose A1 (record your message) the program is paused and then playback is invoked. <n><n>If you choose E you have failed the question: you are asking the computer to answer a phone<n><n>### Example:<n>```<n>Input: "How will you record your message?"<n><n>Response: "Pressing 2 takes you to end menu"<n>```<n><n>## Programming Questions<n>### Question1:<n>What is the range of numbers from a and b, such that 2

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		Answer the below question<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Use the correct form of the verbal phrase "to be careful"<n><n>#### Instructions<n><n>> **Use the correct form of "to be careful"** The man who broke into the house, looked carefully into the room as he moved slowly toward the window.<n><n>### Explanation:In the above sentence, the word "carefully" describes how the thieve checked the room. We don't want to make it sound like a mistake; so we use the correct form of "careful." Because we are describing how the person acted, the correct word is "carefully." This is an adverbial phrase.<n><n>### Input (3):<n><n>> **Use form "should" in the correct verb** You should always be honest.<n><n>### Output:<n>"should" is a modal auxiliary verb. In the above sentence it isn't acting as a subordinating conjunction or a helping verb. Since "you" is a subject that is already performing the action, no helping verb is needed. So to answer this question, use the correct form of the modal auxiliary verb "should"<n><n>### Exercorer:Input:<n>> **Use form'should' in the sentence** We should respect all forms of life.<n><n>### Response<n>You're correct.<n><n>### Requirements:<n>There is no requirement<n><n>### Marking<n>If you answer three questions correctly, you will get a star.<n><n>### Resources:<n>[Link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_sentence_structure)<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would a camper need to do before he or she can start cooking food? Choices:  A: make breakfast B: go hiking C: pack or bag D: light fire E: grab a match<n><n>### Response:		D - grab a match. There are three choices,'making breakfast' and 'going hiking' cannot be done before cooking food, 'pack or bag' is not possible without being certain that no breakfast is needed, and 'light fire' needs something to be lit. As 'grab a match' is the action to complete before cooking, it is the correct answer.<n><n>

Jamie's fat was not weakening or decreasing,  therefore she gave up.<n><n>### Response2:<n>D.Make Larger  --> "Make larger" is defined by Webster as:  "to build or construct larger." Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:At the end of your meal what will a waiter do? Choices:  A: serve food B: eat C: set table D: serve meal E: present bill<n><n>### Response:		D<n>Input:At the end of the meal how is a host/ess thanked? Choices: B: C: D: E: F: G: H: I: J:<n><n>### Response A: B is the only letter that appears twice. C will never show up with the number 1 as a preposition. D, E, F and G will never have their letter in alphabetical order.<n>### In English you might say, "Did you know that the word "hello" has eight letters?"<n>### Or, "The word "hello" is the only English word that is six letters long and has the letters E and L in a row!"<n>### Do either of these sentences sound right to you? (Notice that my sentences refer to words that consist of 5 and 6 letters.)<n>### Choice G: I have used "word" because it is a small "group" of letters that, when used together, communicate a meaning.<n><n>### C: What is the smallest number I can write as three digits that can become 8,314 by using an addition and no subtraction?<n><n>#Explanatory_Response  <n>This section should explain how the task/questions instructions are written. Provide 2-3 sentences that clarify the purpose of the tasks/questions instructions. (Be sure to keep the response as short as possible.)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. Answer the questions with a complete sentence for each.<n>2. How will you complete the task if you have at least four of each color ball?<n><n>### Task:<n><n>How can you tell the order of operations if there is a problem like this one?<n><n>$\displaystyle 67 ‚Äì (6 √ó 5) =?$<n><n>### Explanation:<n>* I used a comma to break down the problem into smaller sections. In the example shown here, the 6-digit number is 67, and then the problem includes an addition (+) and a subtraction (-). I separated a division from multiplication because it's not as easy to identify with so many numbers to find the order of operations. Also, a division has the highest order of operations (left-to-right or outside-to-inside) among all of the numbers with an operation included.<n><n>* This question can only be solved with at least $4$

Because of his mistake, he spent 8 years somewhere. Where was he? Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		<n>*In the above problem, I will make use of both addition and subtraction to arrive at an answer. First of all, I will apply subtraction to solve the card problem because the numbers of cards involved are 2, 4 and 9. It is evident that 7 cards will cover the 2 and 4. It follows that Mara has 7 less than 163 and 9 more than Brenda. After the application of the above mentioned 2 numbers, I will be left with only 1 card, which makes the total of the 3 cards as 9. In a similar manner, Mara will have 9 cards less than 160, which is equivalent to 151. We will subtract 151 from 160, we will be left with only Brenda. In this scenario, 4 cards will be the missing number in the problem which is 154. The reason it is 4 is because 4 cards are more than 146. I will be able to come up with the answer because 4 is one of the solutions to the problem. I will arrive at the answer of 9.<n>*A prisoner has a history of spending 8 years in prison. After that particular period, he goes through a process of getting out of prison. After going through the process, he has a hard time reintegrating to society. He has to face the challenges that may be posed by the community after leaving prison. The hardest thing that a prisoner has to face when he is freed is the situation when people stop believing in him. Many people avoid him, others discriminate him, which makes it more difficult for him to reintegrate to society. When he has to spend the next 8 years, it also becomes difficult for him to survive in these conditions. He may also encounter trouble trying to get a job. The prisoner may find it more difficult than a normal person in his situation. He is left with the option of not engaging in criminal activities. According to him, he may become a better person if he works hard and he will be responsible the next time he has to commit crimes. He will learn from his mistakes by improving his character and trying to be the best person he ever was. There is a need for him to have a plan that will help him overcome the challenges faced by a prisoner. In order to face the

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:He was in a cabin in the woods, through the window he saw a fox where? Choices:  A: indiana B: england C: outside D: on the wall E: picture<n><n>### Response:		C,on the wall<n>A-In Indiana<n>B-England<n>C-Outside<n>D-Picture<n>E-on the wall<n><n>### Reference:https://python.ca/2019/01/04/python-challenge-001/<n><n>Answer: It's good to use the `input()` function but in this example you don't need to use it because in each case you can pass a number to `divisors()` (without input() function and you can input the number using the numbers on your keyboard).<n><n>Here I'm giving you an example to use `input()` you can get the numbers from your keyboard as well.<n><n>\section{Example:}<n><n>\begin{code}<n>d = num1<n>print(f'number 1 is {num1}')<n>input()<n>num2 = int(input(d +'is how much?' + '\n'))<n>d = num1 + num2<n>print(d)<n><n>print('The answer is',(num1 // num2, num1 % num2))<n>\end{code}

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve? Choices:  A: ruined B: clean clothes C: sadness D: attractive appearance E: look better<n><n>### Response:		The man was cleaning clothes to look better (look attractive)<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>In the above instructions I had to describe how to write the task and the required answer. That task is called an instruction.<n><n><n>### Demo:<n><n>The following is an an example that shows what is a demonstration.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>The man was cleaning the clothes for his date,what was he looking to achieve.<n><n>After looking at the the man,s words, you realize that they are not what we consider valid English. What is the instruction for this example.<n>Choices:  A: the man ruined his date B: the man will not have clean clothes<n>C: the man will be sad D: the man will feel good.<n><n>I can see the man doing it for himself after a long day,not for the date.<n><n>If the person is a woman,it is more likely that the man is just cleaning his date,s clothes, not his own.<n><n>### Demo answer : The man wants to feel good<n><n>### Demo code:<n>```py<n>input = 'The man was cleaning his date clothes, what was he looking for?'<n>input = input.split(' ')<n>choices = ['A: the man ruined.','B: the man doesn,'t have clean clothes.','C: the man will feel sad.','D: the man will feel better.','E: the man was cleaning his own clothes.']<n>choices.append('E: the man will feel attractive.')<n>choices.append(input[1])<n>output = input[1]<n><n><n>for i in range(len(choices)):<n>    if input[i]+' is the choice':<n>        output = input[i]<n>        break <n>```<n><n>### Demo output <n>```py<n>The man was cleanin his date clothes, what is he looking for?<n><n>E: the man will be attractive.<n><n><n><n>```<n><n>## Instructions<n>Instructions are a very important part of any task. Instructions is the only key to success.<n>Before any learning task, instructions of that task should be written, even if you are repeating the same task from previous time.<n>Without instructions how can we know what the task is.<n><n><n>## Dem
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		<n>The woman (Janet) dresses herself.<n><n>### Input:(In the following problem, A, B and C are integers; A is not zero.)<n><n>a)B^2+A has a positive remainder upon division by A. Which of the following statements must be true?<n><n>**a)** B and C are odd<n>**b)** B‚â•2<n>**c)** C‚â•3<n><n>**d)** A‚â†1<n><n>### Response<n><n>We can write them as follows;<n>		$B^2 \pmod{A} = {A}({A} - {\left\lfloor\frac{{A}}{2}\right\rfloor} )+{\left\lfloor\sqrt{A}\right\rfloor}$<n>		$C^2 \pmod{B} = {B}{(B} - {\left\floor\frac{{B}}{2}\right\right)}+{\left\floor\sqrt{B}\right\ceil}$<n>		$B \pmod{C} = {B}{( B} - {\left\ceil\frac{{B}}{3}\right\rfloor)} + {\left\ceil\sqrt{B}\ceil} $<n>$A \pmod{B}=\left\floor\sqrt B+\frac{3}{4}\right\floor \floor\sqrt B+1$ (b)$\pmod{C} = \left\floor\sqrt A+2/2-{C} \frac{1}{2}\right\floor +1$ (c)$\pmod{C}= \left\floor\frac{5}{1}-\frac{4}{C}+\frac{5}{2}\right\ceil +1$<n><n>Notice that all of the statements except (d) must be true in order for the remainder to be a positive integer.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>### Instruction:(In the following problem...<n><n>a)Write out the equivalent expressions of "add a few tens to the original number." in words.<n><n>**a)add a few tens to**$n=6$<n>	**add**$10$**$m$ to <n>	`$\sum_{i=1}^i+10$+$i$<n>	$i$<n><n>**A:**$add a few tens to$<n>	$add$10**

It should calculate and display all of the addition and subtraction problems from number1 to number 100 with or without repeats, but only accepting the letters A and B.<n><n>### tutor(subject, A, B)<n>When A and B have values the function should return 2 addition problems (no repeats) and the same amount of addition and subtraction as the number of arguments to the function.<n>When no values are entered the function should return two letters ‚Äò(a)‚Äô and ‚Äò(b)‚Äô<n><n>### Example:<n>tutor("Math", "a", "b") would give the answer<n>A + B = 42 and A - B = 56<n><n>### Example 1:<n>tutor("Physics", "a", "c") would give CORRECT answer<n>A + B + C = 24 and A - B = -96<n><n>### Demostration:<n>tutor("Astronomy", "a", "t").<n><n>

Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Options A-E<n>I think the answer is d because the question is asking for what happens often and the choices are in the same order of what happens after a long day. Jet lag is the last thing that happens with the least choice which is option E.<n><n>#### Options A-D<n>I think the answer for question is A because relocation is the least likely to happen after traveling.<n><n>### Input A: The average student was 20% more likely to succeed on their midterm exam than the average high school student. <n>The average college student was 30% more likely to be a leader in their school than the average high school<n>student. <n><n>#### A.  If the average college student had 18.1% better change of success in school, which of <n>the below answers is CORRECT?<n><n>#### A.A: 0.18118.10% <n><n>  Inverse of 0.18 is 0.18/0.18 = 1<n>     18% = 0.18<n>     20% = 0.2<n>      18/(1.2) = 1.5<n><n>#### B.B: 19.27% <n><n>0.20 x 1.2 = 0.24<n><n>       24% =  19.2%<n><n>     18/(1.32) =  14.62%<n><n>#### C. C: 17.69% <n><n>     17% = 0.80<n>     20%     = 0.20<n>      17/(0.8) = 2.08<n><n>#### D. D: 18.54 % <n><n>     18%     =  0.90           1/0.90 = 1.118<n>     30% = 0,9 *  1.2 =.27<n>      18/(0.27) = 66.6<n><n>#### E.E: 17% <n><n>     0.2        = 16.6%<n>     <n><n><n>#### A.C: 11.76%    B.D: 17.39%

Review the [Application and Interviewer Preparations Worksheet] (https) for the class discussion and write the<n>steps in a process that you would use to complete a job application.<n><n>2.  Select a job application to complete<n><n>3.  Submit an application for the position (paper or online) and post the response here in the discussion board (with<n>the approval of your instructor).<n><n>Part 2: 90 mins<n>  <n>1. Select a minimum of four interview questions that you believe the hiring manager would ask you and submit them with<n>the application.  [Job Interview Questions](https://www.indeed.com/career-advice/interviewing/interview-questions?<n>q=job)<n><n>Part 3:1 hour<n>  <n>1. Read [Three Reasons Why You Didn't Get the Job]<n>(https://www.monster.com/career/article/three-reasons-you-didnt-get-the-job)<n>and explain why you think you may or may not have been selected to interview or why you may or may not get the<n>job.<n><n>### Application and Interview Preparations Worksheet<n><n><n>Please follow the prompts below in chronological order.<n><n>|Step 1 |Step 2 |Step 3 |Step 4 |

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		The response should include the answer to the question posed in the comment in the correct format. The response should include a verbal description of the reasoning and the solution method used along with one complete, original code.<n><n>Answer: There are 3 steps to complete this problem. First is to make a loop with the outer loop set to repeat 3 times because we have to multiply 9, then divide the final result by Janet multiplied by 2 (because Mara has 2x as many cards as Janes) and finally we must add 40 because Mara has 41 cards less than 149.<n>**Code:**<n>    import random, math from math import **f**'def main():<n>        x = int(input('how many cards:"))<n>        y = int(input('where is Mara: '))<n>        z = x + y<n>        m = x * y<n>        a = y / x<n>        b = x * a<n>        c = 40 * a<n>        d = z - c<n>        print(f'a) {a}b) {b}c) {c}d) {d}'**<n>**Execution:**<n>    In the beginning we set the value of the variable **y** to **random.randint(0, 100)**<n>    Then we set the value of **z** to the sum of the 2 values, so **z = x + y**<n>    We then set **m, a, b, **and **c** equal to:<n>    **m = x * y**<n>    ***a = y / x**<n>    *b = x * a<n>    *c = 40 * x<n>    Finally, to finish the calculation we simply subtract 40 from **z** which will be the result!<n>
