Each line of code must contain a single line of input and/or a single line of a computer program that will display the information (to include all variable names where necessary as well as text).<n><n>### Screenshot of answer:<n><n><img src="./screenshot1_1.png" width="500"><n><n>### Explanation:<n>In your answer, if you get in, and put the table input in, the correct computer program will look like this:<n><n><img  src="./screensoot21.png" width=500><n><n>#### Note: you can do this without using a table, but for simplicity sake, just use it.<n><n>### Answer (complete):<n>```<n>var firstRow, lastRow, secondRow, thirdRow, fourthRow, length<n><n>//var firstRow = prompt("Enter the range of firstRow with the maximum number")<n>//var lastRow = prompt("Enter range for lastRow with the minimum number")<n>//var secondRow = prompt("Enter minimum number at the range of Row 2")<n>//var thirdRow = prompt("Enter maximum number at the range of row 3")<n>//var fourthRow = prompt("Enter total number of cards")<n><n>//length = prompt("How many cards do they have?")<n><n>var length = length<n><n>if (length <= 26)<n>	{<n>		length = length * 16<n>	}<n><n>for each (cards in range(1, length))<n>{<n>	if ((length * cards >= 1) ^ length <= 26) <n>		{print(cards + " for the firstRow")<n>	}<n>	else if ((length * cards <= 26) ^ length <= 1)

Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Code:<n>```Javascript<n>let choice = promptInput.toLowerCase();<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>- If choice == D  and choice == D<n>+   Display the string "Their money has become dissipated.".<n>+   Otherwise, display the string "Their<n>+   money has become penultimate.".<n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Code: (Result missing from preview)<n>```Javascript<n>const choose = "D"<n>let choice = prompt.toLowerCase()<n>if(choice == choose){<n>    console.log("Their money has become disssipaded.")<n>}else {<n>    console.log('Their money has become penultiated')<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Resources<n><n>- https://www.freecodecamp.org/<n>- https://www-formbuilder.appspot.com/<n>- https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1X57KMnDQJgOwqUJrFZqCj1GdI85Qn49Y-Q9VHh_rj5I/edit#gid=0<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are so many different pudding varieties available today that picking just one can be a challenge.<n><n>### Input:"How much cheaper is it to buy by the dozen"?<n>### Response:<n><n>The dozen rule in North America means there are 12 in a dozen. The number doesn't seem quite as large as it was when I was a kid. When I was a kid, "there were eleven" was an expression people used, even though there was still a dozen eggs in a dozen. If one was selling something, the trick to fool the customer into thinking they weren't getting a great deal was to use the "dozen" to count the 12, but not the 13.<n><n>The customer might see a dozen eggs for $2 but they expect to pay 12 x $1, or $12. If asked, the person selling them would say "you can get 12 for $4", not mentioning that it was really 13 for $2. So there's a little extra bang for the buck, even before you break it up and have all those lovely single eggs.<n><n><n>### Input : Is the expression "hair of the dog" a reference to dogs having hair?<n>### Response: Yes, it is, but no not about the dog having hair.<n><n>###Input:What is the longest word in the dictionary?<n>###Response:<n><n>It is a tough question to answer. A dictionary is, by definition, a record of the English language. According to the official OED, it is a word, used correctly in a sentence, that is part of the English language. The current edition of the dictionary is 12,000 pages long and has a 30 million word index. It defines more than 640,000 words, not including prefixes, prefixes, and suffixes.<n><n>###Response: It is a tough question, but it is actually a bit easier than it seems.<n><n>A dictionary doesn't just have definitions. It also contains the history and use of words. All the words of the English language are recorded in dictionaries, even if they are not always listed as being in the English language. When all of these items are recorded, they can be used as a guide to the language.<n><n>Many

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What could you buy in a bookstore? Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demongstration:<n>Input:"I like applesauce." is equivalent to _______.<n>Answer:  A: I don't like applesauce.<n><n>### Input<n>A dog is being walked by two adults. The dog is in front of the adults. The dog runs behind the adults. This is equivalent to ________.<n><n>Answer:  A - I'm behind the two adults.<n><n>### Comment<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Instructon:Answer this true false question.<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n><n>```jsx<n>function checkAnswereTrueFalse(data) {<n>  const x = document.querySelectorAll(data.elementToFind);<n>  const test = document.querySelectorAll('[data-testid=true-false-answer]')<n>  return new HTMLCollection(x)<n>}<n><n>function addTestAndAns(x) {<n>    function Answers() {<n>    const question = x.querySelector('div')<n> <n>    question.onsubmit = (event) => {<n>      const button = document.querySelector('button')<n>     <n>            if(event.target.value && typeof event.target.value === "boolean"){<n>              if(event.target!== "true" &&!event.target === "false"){<n>                event.preventDefault();<n>                button.querySelector('div').innerHTML = "That is not a logical answer"<n>                return false;<n>              }<n>              else<n>                button.querySelector(btn_ans).innerHTML = "Logically Correct"<n>              return true<n>            }<n>            else<n>              button.querySelector(btnw_ans).innerHTML =event.target.value<n>              return false<n>        <n>        }<n>      checkAnwareAndRun(test[0].getAttribute('data-testid'), Answers.bind(test[0]) ())<n>  }<n>  return Answers();<n>}<n><n>checkAns(checkAnwareAndRun(data.elementToCheck, addAnswerAndAns(data.elementToAdd()))); <n><n>```<n>

Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Give three sentences describing a dog<n><n>### Response 1:<n>Dogs are mammals. <n>They are small animals. They are domestic animals.<n><n>### Response2:<n>Dogs are the most popular pet in Australia. They look like wolves. They have 4 legs.<n>They run quickly. Dogs are good for health.<n><n>### Note: Do not alter the format of this question (ie. do not remove the 6 bullets and the 2 sentences).<n><n><n>### Input<n>We have an array of m items each with n values. How many items can we remove such that the average values do not change? The array is sorted.<n><n>### Option 1:  n items<n>### Option 2:  ‚àû items (we can remove any m items.<n><n>### Solution<n>```javascript<n>function calcAverage(array, itemCount, sum) {<n>  let counter = 0;<n>  for (let i = 0; i < sum; i++) {<n>    sum -= Number.parseFloat(array[i]);<n>    counter++;<n>  }<n>  return (1 / counter * counter);<n>}<n>```<n>```javascript<n>function averageWithoutDecrease(array = [9, 6, 8, 4]) {<n>  const itemCount = array.length;<n>  const sum = 0;<n><n>  const decrease = itemCount;<n>  while (decrease--) {<n>    let current = Math.abs(array.pop() - array[parseInt(decrease)]);    <n>    if (current < 1) {<n>      return sum;<n>    }<n>    sum -= current;<n>  } <n>  <n>  return sum / itemCount;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input1:<n>The average is calculated as follows:<n><n>2/5 of the 100 students at a grade-school are taking mathematics. 40% of the rest of the students are taking Spanish. 47% of those taking a foreign language are women. There are 133 students taking a foreign language. How many girls are foreign language students?<n><n>```javascript<n>exports.getGirlsWhoSpeakForeign1 = (arr) => {<n>  const boys = arr.filter((arrItem)=

The correct contraction is "aren't". <n><n>### InputA: You can't always judge a book by reading its cover. B: You can judge a book by reading it's cover." One example is provided below (under "Demonstration"). Choose one word or phrase from the two choices to use for each blank. <n><n>### Instrutio:Write as many sentences as you ca as you can with the instructions (in bold)and with each of the expressions in the left column. Write each phrase exactly as you see it here. <n><n>## Demostration:<n>You will be given three words. You must make each word into a different part of speech. Write it down so that you can remember it. <n><n>## Demo:<n>Advantage (noun) ‚Üí Advantageous (adjective) ‚Üí <n><n>## Input:You can't always judge and book by reading its cover (idiom)<n><n>## Demo: <n>Book (noun)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		Janitor got the pail upstairs in the bathroom from wishing well because it says there that Janitor got his pail upstairs from where.<n><n>### Input:"That is the way all Americans used to vote, until the Constitution was changed." How is this statement incorrect?<n><n>Choice 1: We have only one president at a time.<n><n>Choice 2: Vote is a verb.<n><n>Choice 3: Vote is a process. You can vote for someone.<n><n>Choice 4: The Constitution makes you vote in a uniform way.<n><n>### Comment: We now vote on various people who can hold an office. We vote to elect a person by voting to elect. It is incorrect in the sense that vote is a procedure and not a verb, a word denoting an action. <n><n>### Input, A: There has been a large increase in the number of shirts in the shirt sales room.<n><n>### Response, A: How did you know?<n><n>Comment: A comment like this is useful because it encourages students to look at their own work and see the mistakes that exist. The Comments feature allows students to ask for help about how to write comments.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>Explanation of how to use the Comments to provide further assistance to students is shown here. An explanation of how to use the Explanations appears later in these instructions.<n><n>### Example<n><n>Response, A: It is true that there has been an increase in the number of items in the shirt salesroom, but that doesn't prove it.<n><n>Comment, A: This is an increase in the number, but not necessarily an increase in the number that are currently in the salesroom.<n><n>Comment, B: Why is this an increase? What does "number of shirts" mean? How is that the same as what is currently in the salesroom?<n><n>Comment, C: How do we know it's true?<n><n>### Excited to See This<n><n>Some students might be anxious to see what their teachers have to write in their Comments. <n><n>## How to Give Comments to Other Students<n><n>Here is an example of how students can give comments to each other. Note the three choices the student can make for how their comment is answered.<n><n>### Problem: What is the answer

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:James was delayed for a couple of hours because he had a connection.  Where might his connection be? Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>read -p 'Please choose the answer and press enter: (1-5)' -n 1 -r ANSWER<n><n>case "$ANSWER" in<n>    1)  Answer=A<n>    printf "$Answer\n\n"<n>    ;;<n>    2)  Answer=B<n>    printf "$Answer and more\n\n" <n>    ;;<n>    3)  Answer=C<n>    printf "$Answer  is on its way\n\n"    <n>    ;;<n>    4)  Answer=D<n>    printf "$Answer is the internet\n\n"   <n>    ;;<n>    5)  Answer=E<n>    printf "$Answer loves you\n\n"  <n>    ;;<n>esac<n><n>exit 0<n>```<n>	<n><n><n>### Input<n>	<n><n><n><n>The number of seconds that the clock shows is 51.<n>The clock also shows the time of day, half past 3.<n>The clock hands make a triangle with one end of the arrow shape at 5 seconds after the 12.<n><n>What time is it displayed on the clock?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```bash<n>#/bin/bash<n><n>#Ask a question<n>read -p 'What time is it?\n'  TIME<n>#Ask another question related to the time asked for<n>read -p 'How do you get home?\n'  ROUTE<n>#Ask another questino<n>read -p 'Where are you moving?\n'  CURRENT_HOME<n>#Create the final response<n>echo "Good luck getting home! Thanks for asking. See ya!"<n>```<n>	<n>### Solution<n>```bash<n>#! /bin/bash<n><n>time=3456<n><n>echo "Hey! $time is a funny number"<n><n>echo "It's not just a number. It's something else that we call a palindrome"<n><n>echo "That's right"<n><n>echo "I didn't think you'd answer like that"<n><n>echo "This number is a palindrome" <n><n>echo "What does a palindrome means?"<n><n>echo "It means that that number reads just as well forwards than backwards and that
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: thoughtful<n><n>### Explanation justification:<n>Opposite of foolhardy = thoughtful<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If a person does something to hurt someone else, they might do what? Choices:  A: feel sorry B: trust god C: cross street D: ride a bike E: lend money<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>*If a person does something wrong, they should be sorry. You can trust God with everything.<n><n>#### Explanation:- <n><n>##### üìñ Explanation:-<n><n>### Instructions: Write a program that counts the total number of correct guesses for three rounds of the children‚Äôs guessing game.<n><n>### Guessing Game Example<n><n>*Teacher<n><n>- "You pick a number between five and eight."<n><n>- "I pick a number less than eight" or "I pick a number larger than six"<n><n>- "You tell me if I'm right or wrong."<n><n>*Game<n><n>- First the teacher picks a number such as 6<n>- Then student picks between 1 and 3,<n>- If the first pick is less than 6, the student loses and the round is over<n>- If the first option is greater than 6, the teacher repeats the game with a correct guess<n>- The student can win or lose<n><n>### Input :<n>1 - 2 - 3<n><n>1 is the correct answer in the first round for the student.<n><n>**Student Guess<n><n>1<n><n>**Teacher Guess<n><n>**Student wins the round, because the first guess from the teacher was less than the picked number 1, in first attempt by student.<n><n>4<n><n>**Student wins<n><n>3 is the best answer in the second round for the student. 1 is incorrect and 4 is greater than 3 and 2 is incorrect in the second pick from the student.<n><n>5<n><n>**Teachers wins<n><n>8 is the correct number to pick in the third round for the teacher<n><n>**Student Guest<n><n><n>**Teachr Guest<n><n>

Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Comments<n>- This instruction may need to be repeated for additional demonstrations.<n>- Consider a task where the number of students is not known.<n>- Expand the task to allow a response.<n>- Have the students ask "Yes or No" questions.<n>- Keep students on task.<n>- Demonstrate a simple task first then a more involved task.<n>- Consider modeling this technique only for the first activity.<n>- Demonstrable tasks to address in an IEP may need a demonstration before the students can be given the task.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>### Input:If clothes have developed a smell and can't be washed what should you do with them? Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		Choose B.<n><n>### Input A and B:<n>Input A: If there were 10 apples in a box and there are now 8, how many more? Choices: 1:8   2:10   3:six   4:none<n>Input B: If the box now contained 40 apples, how many more apples did you have in the box? Choices: 4: 4   5:6  	6:7   7:10  8:12  9:32  10:52<n><n>### Response A:<n>I need 6 more apples to bring me back to 10<n><n>### Response B:<n>I need 10 apples to bring me to 40 apples.<n><n>### Example:<n>If a box contained 10 apples and there were 8 after, I would need 6 more appiles to get back to 10. If the box now contained a total of 40 apples all together, I needed 10 apples back.<n>
